claims_summary: Washington Post owner with $600M CIA cloud contract awarded same period as newspaper purchase (2013), creates structural conflict of interest for national security coverage

washington_post_purchase: October 2013: Bezos purchases WaPo for $250 million (Washington Post announcement)
Personal purchase: Not Amazon corporate, but Bezos personally
Marty Baron: Executive editor maintained editorial independence claims
Financial terms: $250M purchase price publicly disclosed
cia_cloud_contract: 2013: AWS awarded $600M CIA cloud contract (Federal procurement records)
Timing: Same period as WaPo purchase (months apart)
AWS IC contracts: Expand to billions over subsequent years
snowden_paradox: June 2013: Washington Post begins publishing Snowden NSA leaks
Timeline shows WaPo published leaks embarrassing to IC while owner negotiated IC contracts
Subsequent WaPo coverage: Generally more favorable to intelligence community
conflict_of_interest: Structural conflict: Newspaper owner has financial incentive to maintain IC relationships
AWS dependence: Billions in IC contracts create leverage
Editorial independence claimed but financially questionable
WaPo coverage analysis: National security reporting generally IC-friendly post-Bezos
Alternative explanation: Coincidental timing, legitimate editorial independence
pentagon_contracts: JEDI competition: Amazon competed for $10B Pentagon cloud contract
Blue Origin: National security launch contracts
DoD relationships: Multiple defense contracts beyond CIA
Financial scale: IC/DoD contracts worth billions annually

validation_status: WaPo purchase and CIA contract timing well-documented through public records - editorial influence claims disputed, circumstantial evidence suggests conflict but direct causation difficult to prove
